title: Why hasn't Karma been considered for the mid-year mage update?
body: Now that her shield explosion is removed, all her abilities completely lack uniqueness and look like very close variations to skills already in the game. It's a shame really, she would have really benefited from a class update.

replies.body: She's a support.
Primary: Mage.

Morgana Primary: Mage
Alistar Not even listed as a support
Syndra Secondary: Support
Im beginning to think these assignments are completely arbitrary...
EDIT I guess they changed that Alistar thing recently, but my point stands.

Morgana became a powerful support when CC Tank Supports were spammed every game, and the Utility Supports that destroyed her were weak/risky.

Before that season, everyone would have laughed at your pick, and say that you are a worse troll than the Nida "Support".

She still is amazing as a Mid Laner 
(or anywhere imo), but people started to play her as a support just for having a Snowbally Support, but with more Utility and higher pick potential (for kills). Also, as mentioned before, if she gets into a favourable Match-Up, she will just nullify the opposing Support.

> [{quoted}](name=Scarborough Fair,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=u8w2u3ka,comment-id=00030000,timestamp=2016-02-23T18:46:00.115+0000)
>
> Primary: Mage.

And yet shes been balanced for the support role, unlike lux and morgana...
Since when?

> [{quoted}](name=Anu3isII,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=u8w2u3ka,comment-id=0003000000000000,timestamp=2016-02-23T21:03:33.126+0000)
>
> Since when?

In the pre-season she was given increased mana regen, which is the treatment they gave to support mages. Solo lane mages were given flat mana buffs. To Riot, Karma is a support.

Morgana, Zyra, Lulu and Zilean got this buff/change too.

Those champions may be considered supports by some people (even Riot) but they surely are good Mages too.

From my point of view, some of these champions were buffed as "supports" to actually buff them directly, by increasing their Mana Regen compared to the other champions. The Max Mana changes to the other mages can't be really compared to these huge Mana Regen buffs.

They may consider Karma a support, but ,from my point of view, she excels in a Solo Lane as Supportive Mage.

> [{quoted}](name=Anu3isII,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=u8w2u3ka,comment-id=000300000000000000000000,timestamp=2016-02-23T21:54:46.725+0000)
>
> Morgana, Zyra, Lulu and Zilean got this buff/change too.
> 
> Those champions may be considered supports by some people (even Riot) but they surely are good Mages too.
> 
> From my point of view, some of these champions were buffed as "supports" to actually buff them directly, by increasing their Mana Regen compared to the other champions. The Max Mana changes to the other mages can't be really compared to these huge Mana Regen buffs.
> 
> They may consider Karma a support, but ,from my point of view, she excels in a Solo Lane as Supportive Mage.

Lulu is the only champion in that list who isn't primarily played as support. Morgana, Zyra and Zilean all considered support their primary role when the pre-season came about and that is why they got buffed in that way. Lulu is confusing but is against the trend.

Your point of view regarding how well they do in solo lanes doesn't matter - Riot made the changes so their thoughts are the relevant ones. I find everyone on that list to be an excellent solo laner and love playing Zyra mid myself but that doesn't change that Riot considers them supports. The theory that they got mana regen buffs because Riot wanted to buff them makes no sense - first of all it's far too large a coincidence that Riot randomly wanted to buff basically every champion who can be both a support and a solo laner and second of all, there is absolutely no way that they'd desire to buff either Lulu or Morgana. Finally, if Riot were really deciding to buff champions like Karma and Zyra, then why not various other weak champions that got mana buffs? Why would they have left Syndra, who they've discussed being weak, with a paltry +50 base mana? It makes no sense.

The chances that Riot buffed Karma in exactly the same way that they buffed every single support for reasons other than thinking she's a support are ridiculously slim. It's almost certain that Riot balance her as a support and the pre-season changes are the perfect example of that. "Maybe they just wanted to make Karma better?" is a huge stretch with no real basis.
Again. Riot made her that way and took away core things from her old kit that could have been made in a new way. Riot did it all on purpose.

Riot has already said that it's because Karma is a support-mage instead of just the generic 'mage'.

There are a bunch of mages in the game that are just generic mages and they kind of stomp all over each other's feet to find a reason to be picked.

Pretty much. There are enough mages in LoL we can't do work on all of them at once. As a result we decided to focus our efforts on mages from two subcategories, those with sustained damage patterns (Vlad, Malz, Vel'Koz, Cass, Brand to some degree) or those that revolve a lot around getting the right pick at a decent range (Zyra, Brand to some degree). We'll also be doing some smaller scope work on a number of other mages from those sub classes, though are still figuring out which ones at present.

Some of the more supportive mages, Karma especially, could certainly do with some work to make them more distinct. A lot of the champs in that category though do feel like they're overall better off in that regard though, Ori and Morg especially. We concluded as a result that it was more valuable to focus our work on other groups for the mid year mage update.

So, is that a no in terms of whether Karma will be updated, or a yes that Karma will be updated?

You have not pretty much answered the intended question behind the question on hand - Are we going to see changes made to Karma?

Supportive Mages are still Mages in nature, Ori and Morg are definitely distinct enough, however Karma is not on their level of distinction. 

Apart from having different power spikes in game, Karma also plays out differently as to how she was first envisioned. 

What you've only mentioned in your reply was why X champion was focused over Y, while contradicting yourself by acknowledging you felt the same way about Y champion lacking distinction. Karma suffers from the same problem with the rest of champions slated for an update (lack of distinction) yet we're not considering her because of her class, even though your first concern with the update were champions who lacked and needed more distinction. I bet that many Karma players want to know what you are allowed to say more about her because communication between the Karma fanbase and the balance team is a literal mess at the moment.

Also, it took a number of Karma-related threads for some time just to elicit a response from you too, so tell us if Riot is going to relook at her case file and decide if she can use a second-rework, not just an update.

We're not planning any major changes to Karma at present. 

From our perspective original Karma had a number of problems that left her pretty non functional much of the time, unhealthy at other times and good fun at some points too. That prompted a rework which, overall, hasn't been particularly successful. It was done at a time when we didn't have a dedicated team for rewoks and frankly it shows in her kit. Revised Karma's a more functional, healthy champion, but also in many ways a pretty bland one, with a lot of tools on her kit that feel too familiar, even if there's some interesting nuance to their use. I wouldn't say she was weak, I'd certainly agree she wasn't sufficiently satisfying or distinct though.

As to why we're not working on Karma at present the short version is that we felt other champions needed the work more or would benefit from it more. Concentrating the team's focus onto particular sub classes is also something we believe yields good results (multiple people exploring the same concepts at the same time results in better discussion, team support). As above pick mages and sustained damage mages are the classes that, overall, we felt would most benefit from some focused work, so we've chosen to work on those at this time.

Thank you Meddler. I've dreamed of seeing a redpost in a Karma thread.
I really respect the work you guys put into keeping this game and older champions up to date, and I agree, that reworking champions as groups makes more sense for the game.

But if I may ask **one **question:
> Revised Karma's a more functional, healthy champion, but also in many ways a pretty bland one, with a lot of tools on her kit that feel too familiar, even if there's some interesting nuance to their use

I totally agree. But following this logic, don't you think that [5.10 ](http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/patch/patch-510-notes)was a mistake too? We have a lot of "get more of the same" type ultimates (Rengar, Heimer, LeBlanc), so was it a good idea to make her RW and RE "more root" and "more shield" instead of keeping the interesting nuances of "heal and damage" and "shield and damage" alive?

So does this mean that after pick mages and sustained mages, the next class of mages (assuming the update is still ongoing) will focus on the likes of Karma? Or are we looking at this for a 2017 change instead? I'm very curious why you allowed Ori and Morg to function the way they are now (having the right mix of damage and utility to carry), yet Karma was the one who was completely butchered. 
 
I'm guessing that by Revised Karma, you were effectively referring to 5.10 Karma, not reworked Karma in general. It's good to know you are acknowledging Karma is bland and her tools are too familiar, there is also a lack of interesting gameplay to her. Above all, the most important thing is that she's not satisfying to play. 

 But we've also heard the same words over and over again, 

> we felt other champions needed the work more or would benefit from it more.

How can you efficiently convince the player base that you care about a particular champion ie: Yorick & Taric, but on the other hand, you and the rest of the team can't be bothered to revise Karma's failed case, or be proactive/responsive towards players who talked about her until today?

Karma's issue has been going on for at 3 years (soon) now, and I can't think of any other fanbase who has suffered that long. Sure, you can argue Taric and Yorick is in need of a rework, but Karma's case is that her reworked failed to deliver and was left sitting in the dust, never again to be discussed, unlike Taric or Yorick. 

What is the long version to your response if I may ask? Or better yet, are you going to look at Karma's old kit and revise from there? I don't like the idea of waiting for 4 years for a party to fix their failure. Simply because the same words and reasons have been repeated over again and they don't seem satisfactory enough. Ryze rework's a simple incident where players felt the team didn't prioritize Karma for her to have a second rework.Yet Ryze is planned for major changes a year after his recent rework, what about Karma? 

What I understand is that you and the rest of the team have taken full responsibility by admitting your rework was a failure, but not giving any words to convince the Karma player base to be patient and have faith in you. I think the faith on a player base is important, because they are the ones providing feedback to you. If I were to give you a timeline starting from now, when exactly do you think you can start proposing the changes to Karma again? Give us a tentative/proposed timeline, let's see how well the team will keep to their words.

Do you not read the boards at all?  Just one little post and then are done with it..eliciting a tantrum because you only know 1/4 of the story?  Get your facts straight before you come onto the boards please.  

> How can you efficiently convince the player base that you care about a particular champion ie: Yorick & Taric, but on the other hand, you and the rest of the team can't be bothered to revise Karma's failed case, or be proactive/responsive towards players who talked about her until today?

Ignorant.  It takes time and effort to work on champs.  Can't just be instantly changed, especially when they are working on a bunch of other champions.  Do you expect them to drop what they are doing just to work on this one champ that you and a handful of other people are so passionate about for some reason?  Do you expect Riot to hire one person for each champion so that when people like you come on the boards to bitch about them they can fix stuff instantly?  You gonna fork over their salary?

> Karma's issue has been going on for at 3 years (soon) now, and I can't think of any other fanbase who has suffered that long. Sure, you can argue Taric and Yorick is in need of a rework, but Karma's case is that her reworked failed to deliver and was left sitting in the dust, never again to be discussed, unlike Taric or Yorick.

Well, at least you acknowledge the Taric and Yorick who have never received any love whatsoever.  At least they made an attempt on Karma, but they already acknowledged, again, that it wasn't as successful as they had hoped. 

> I don't like the idea of waiting for 4 years for a party to fix their failure.

God damn you are such a whiny child!  Have you seriously not noticed that Riot is actively updating every class and now has a specific team dedicated to do so compared to previous reworks?  They can't get to every champ at once and aren't going to choose champs based on how many people bitch about X champion.  

> If I were to give you a timeline starting from now, when exactly do you think you can start proposing the changes to Karma again? Give us a tentative/proposed timeline, let's see how well the team will keep to their words.

They can't do that dude.  Seriously...read the boards more.  Stop coming on here with minimal knowledge on what they do and how they run things.

Actually I do expected them work on previously worked on champions that have failed in being what they need to be. I don't think is fucking fair to effectively destroy a champion someone enjoys and basically abandon it after the fact.

> [{quoted}](name=Vesivian,realm=OCE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=u8w2u3ka,comment-id=00040000000300000000,timestamp=2016-02-24T07:06:14.235+0000)
>
> Karma's failed case

Karma wasn't a failure, she just wasn't totally perfect either. Stop pretending she isn't a decent champion or, even more outlandish, that she isn't better than she was pre-rework.

> That prompted a rework which, overall, **hasn't been particularly successful**. It was done at a time when **we didn't have a dedicated team for rewoks and frankly it shows in her kit**.

I'll leave it here, whether you like it or not. If you're going to analyze word by word, then go ahead and tell people Karma wasn't a failure, but she wasn't perfect either. The idea was Karma didn't live up to the vision of rework, that alone says failure. 

> I wouldn't say she was weak, **I'd certainly agree she wasn't sufficiently satisfying or distinct though**.

Failure. How? Because she lacks distinction. Failure. Failure. Failure. If you're telling me you think Karma is decent because she isn't weak, it's not an argument. Rather, look at what whether Karma was cohesively designed.
He's just a riot booty licker who can't accept that they made a mistake....don't mind him

The sad thing is it wouldn't even take much to make Karma satisfying or distinct. A partial revert of those awful 5.10 changes would make her a little more distinct and a whole lot more satisfying. At least until you guys can fully focus on her, don't let her stay as she is, it really sucks for those of us who liked her before.

Karma is not bland. She is the most interesting non-melee/Thresh support in the game and the most interesting non-Syndra/Ori mage in the game at present. 

Her kit is both fluid and versatile. She is equally extremely fun to kite multiple enemies at once with while being able to spark her whole team for an engage and not be overpowered. 

She is the only support-mage with a kit that allows her to go into other lanes and not just be a fed support. Her kit actually allows her to play two roles with different play styles. Who else can easily fit into another lane now? Lulu. What does Lulu do? Play support in another lane with more gold.

Karma can carry a team both as a carry and an enabler and does it with interesting multipurpose abilities. I think all the supports that had their ability to go outside the role gutted should be altered to be on Karma's level. 

She's never oppressive unless you let her be and she's never completely out of options in a match unless she really screwed up and not linear in doing so.

Again, look at Lulu. If she's ahead, she just cockblocks really hard for her team with a repetitive pattern. If she's behind, she has the option of cockblocking as hard as she can for her team in hopes that they pull through with the same repetitive pattern.

Again, not only is Karma not bland but she is the ideal support design. She has way more decisions available in her kit than other supports and is still balanced.

{{champion:53}} {{champion:25}} {{champion:37}} {{champion:16}} {{champion:40}} {{champion:117}}  

You know what separates successful players of these champs from bots? Runes, Masteries, Item actives and knowing when to cast one of a few generic solutions to a situation in the form of a sequence of abilities or at times spamming one ability whenever it's off CD. I mean just look at Janna, anyone with enough game knowledge picks her up and statistically does well with her more often than not, don't need to know Janna just the times to use her sequences.

And tbh, even the aforementioned Thresh is pretty linear in the average hands.

Edit- AND even the aforementioned melee supports aren't all that amazing in comparison. Leona's a cc bot whose intermediate bot would probably do well in Silver with the runes/masteries. Alistar... well, he recently got changed so it's easier to fire off a sequence of abilities. And I guess there's Tahm, the most complex linear champ there is really. Loaded with interesting stuff in a vacuum but only has 2 real impactful moves that are actually the same ability.

**TLDR **Karma isn't bland and especially isn't bland if compared to most other champs in her class[es].

Karms is bland. There are certain things part of her current kit that do help her. What really lacking is a fun kit that plays off her theme and a identity. I'm sorry that I have to disagree with you.

Karma's Q and Q+R is bland.
Karma's W and W+R is bland, does no damage, and doesn't fit her theme.
Karma's E+R is a watered down version of Iron Locket Solari, with a speed boost that is not as rewarding as you think . . . . not at the expense of her character and damage.
Karma's R is not bad but can you sit here and tell me there is no other way they can make this better?
Karma's passive promotes that she needs to do damage on champions to cast her abilities, which doesn't help with her scaling into late game or kit.

I completely disagree with everything you say. Is Karma a bad champion right now? No. Is she bad compared to the list of champions you listed? Yes. Can she be played well with the right items? Yes but that is not the case though. A champion shouldn't have to be viable because of weapons. A champion should be fun to play because of their identity and kit, which is something Karma lack with Riot's botched rework.

Of course you are not. You are going to go back to tanks, juggernauts, then assassins and then you will get to "support mages". Karma is listed as a mage but you insist on making her a support because of the bland kit you gave her. Sometimes I feel that you purposely gave her this kit to bottleneck her as a support so you have an excuse. Everyone tired of reading your excuses. You attempted to rework this champion and it backfired. Your team admits that you failed at her rework and what do you do? You make a promise you will come back to it, after you work on champions you feel deserve your time more.

Let's talk about how you spent the entire year of 2015 working on tank and juggernauts. You say you are going back to tanks and juggernauts after the mid year mage update. You guys say that there are other champions that need your attention at the moment, but that is not the case. The problems with juggernauts and tanks are not the champions. The problem are the items you introduced. I'm sorry Meddler, your reasoning is a complete lie.

After spending MORE time on juggernauts and tanks you are going BACK to assassins that you just spent some time on. Are we going to have another year where you spend your entire time on {{champion:238}} and {{champion:107}} . WAIT I predict you are going to spend the rest of the year on {{champion:91}} , your new poster child. You just implemented a whole bunch of assassin changes and an item to help them.

I'm sorry Riot you priorities are jacked up. You admit you screwed up on reworks for champions like {{champion:43}} {{champion:82}} {{champion:13}} . Instead of coming up with an excuse as to why you are to lazy to rectify your mistakes, fix AT LEAST the champions you made worse. Karma has no identity anymore, her kit is bland, you removed core things from her kit that players loved, and more. Morde is a mess. Ryze has yet to be anywhere he needs to be. What is your response Meddler? "We feel that changes to Talon and Soraka take priority over the botched reworks we admit to messing up on. We apologize for the miscommunication." Stop apologize for no miscommunication and get to working on the mistakes you made. Fans of these champions will have respect for you going back and fixing these champions you PROMISED to make better. What you are doing now is alienating them with champions that don't need the scope of work you screwed up on.

I just cannot understand why you are trying to justify putting Karma in the support mage update when you acknowledge you failed to give her a distinctive and rewarding kit. YOU ADMIT THAT. What do you do? You tell us she is almost the last champion on your list of updating. Did Karma really need to be put after {{champion:63}} and {{champion:161}}? Definitely not because it hasn't been three years since you messed around with their identity and kit in the game and screw them up.

I'm sorry Riot. I have no respect for you as game developers if you fail to realize your mistakes and rectify them. I really cannot comprehend your decision making to make Karma, Morde, and Ryze players wait another year or two so you can feel justified in your decision to do so. It makes your entire team look incompetent and bad decision makers. You promised work on champions you own up to failing with you. It has been three years and you continue to place Karma below your poster child champions. It's time you get over your huge egos and get to work on these champions you failed with.

I know the difference between a Yorrik and Taric rework. I am not putting Karma, Morde, and Ryze on that pedestal.

Karma's always been a mid pick for at least some pros. 

Hell, awhile back bjergsen got a pentakill with her in the lcs. 

That's not to say her kit's fine, it does have some problems. 

You know how people always go out and try a new pick they see in pro play, especially when that champion gets a pentakill? 

Karma's pickrate barely went up after that and then it went back down to what it normally was after a little bit. No one even complained about seeing people trying Karma mid because a pro did it, because barely anyone did after they tried it the first time. 

Karma's reworked sort of failed to fix what some of her problems were. (I'm talking kit problems and not weaknesses)

IIRC one of the reasons she was reworked so massively was because she was too reliant on Mantra. 

And she still is. 

But the problem is that to most people that played her, they made her a lot less fun, at least compared to how she use to be.

Anyways, I think her problem isn't that she isn't good, it's that her kit feels "meh" and boring to most people. 

Not to mention her thematic could be played out much, much better.

Her rework isn't as completely terrible as I make it out to be, though. 

It's still pretty satisfying in it's own right and it would be criminal to say that it was a complete failure.
